metadata.title: Estate Tax Calculator (Estimate & Scenario Planner)
metadata.description: Multi-mode estate tax estimator that helps you approximate federal and potential state estate tax exposure after debts, deductions, gifts, and exemptions. Includes a simple quick estimate, a detailed adjustment mode for marital or special deductions, and a state-adjusted scenario for jurisdictions with separate estate taxes.

simple_estimate.label: Simple estimate
simple_estimate.description: Quick calculation: subtract liabilities and deductions, apply exemption, then apply an assumed federal marginal rate to compute an estimated federal tax liability.

detailed_estimate.label: Detailed estimate (deductions & marital adjustment)
detailed_estimate.description: Includes a field for explicit marital deduction amount and other itemized adjustments so you may refine the taxable estate before applying an assumed federal rate.

state_adjusted.label: State-adjusted estimate (flag state exposure)
state_adjusted.description: Adds a user-provided assumed state rate when the chosen jurisdiction levies an estate tax. This is an estimate only; state rules vary widely.

fields.label: Gross estate value (sum of worldwide assets)
Taxable lifetime gifts (subject to gift/estate offset)
Assumed effective federal marginal rate (enter as decimal)
Does the decedent's state impose an estate tax?
Assumed state effective rate (enter as decimal)
Marital deduction amount (if claiming portability or marital deduction)

introduction: This tool provides scenario-based estimates of estate tax exposure. It is intended to help you understand order-of-magnitude outcomes after subtracting debts, administration costs, and allowable deductions, then applying an exemption and assumed tax rates.

Estimates are not a substitute for professional tax or estate planning advice. Laws and exemption amounts change; enter current exemption values and, when relevant, consult counsel for valuation, basis adjustments, and state-specific rules.
methodology: Calculations follow standard accounting order: determine gross estate, subtract allowable liabilities and deductions to compute the net estate, reduce by applicable exemptions and reported lifetime taxable gifts to produce a taxable estate, and apply an assumed effective tax rate to estimate liability.

Security, privacy, and development practices for this tool align with published standards for trustworthy systems and risk management. See NIST Special Publications and ISO risk-management guidance cited below for controls and system development practices.
how_is_calculated: Step 1: Net estate = gross_estate_value - debts_total - funeral_costs - allowable_deductions
Step 2: Taxable estate = max(Net estate - federal_exemption_amount - taxable_gifts, 0)
Step 3 (simple): Estimated federal tax = Taxable estate × assumed_federal_rate
Step 4 (state-adjusted): Estimated state tax = If state_has_estate_tax == yes then Taxable estate × assumed_state_rate else 0; Total estimated tax = Estimated federal tax + Estimated state tax
examples: Example 1 — Quick estimate: Gross estate $2,000,000; debts & deductions $200,000; federal exemption $12,900,000; taxable estate becomes zero, estimated federal tax $0.

Example 2 — State-adjusted: Gross estate $15,000,000; debts & deductions $500,000; federal exemption $13,000,000; taxable estate $1,500,000. With assumed federal rate 0.40 and assumed state rate 0.05, estimated federal tax $600,000 and state tax $75,000; total $675,000.

faqs.question: Is this an official tax calculation?
faqs.answer: No. This is an estimate tool for planning and scenario comparison only. It does not replace filings, formal valuations, or professional advice. Use current statutory exemption numbers and consult a tax attorney or CPA for filing and compliance.

faqs.question: How should I choose the assumed federal rate?
faqs.answer: The assumed federal rate is a user-entered effective marginal estimate that approximates the progressive tax schedule. For conservative planning, use the top marginal rates applicable to the portion of the estate above the exemption; a tax professional can produce an exact bracketed computation.

faqs.question: Does this include state estate or inheritance taxes?
faqs.answer: This tool can include a user-specified state rate when a jurisdiction imposes an estate tax, but it does not encode every state’s brackets, exemptions, or credits. Confirm state-specific rules with state tax authorities or counsel.

faqs.question: How accurate are the results?
faqs.answer: Accuracy depends on the correctness of your inputs (asset values, debts, deduction amounts, exemption chosen, and assumed rates). This tool provides estimates only. See the Accuracy & Compliance note in citations for recommended verification standards.

glossary.definition: Total value of all assets and property owned by the decedent at death (worldwide) before debts, expenses, and deductions.
Gross estate minus debts, administration costs, and allowable deductions used to determine the estate subject to exemptions.
Net estate reduced by statutory exemptions (e.g., federal unified credit/exemption) and adjusted for taxable gifts; this base is used to compute estate tax.

Rules that allow transfers to a surviving spouse to be deducted from the taxable estate or for unused exemption amounts of a deceased spouse to be transferred (portability), subject to specific election and documentation rules.
User-provided effective marginal tax rate used for approximation; conservative planning should be based on bracketed schedule calculations by a professional.
